metadata.case_name: Ghee Varghese v. Commissioner of Gift Tax

facts.text: The assessee was the sole proprietor of the business run under the name and style of Travancore Timbers and Products at Kottayam.

The assessee converted the proprietary business into a partnership business by means of a deed of partnership dated August 1, 1963. The partnership consisted of the assessee and his two daughters (one married, one unmarried).
The capital of the partnership was Rs. 4,00,000/-. The assessee contributed Rs. 3,50,000/- and each daughter Rs. 25,000/- (effected by transfer from assessee's account to each daughter's account).

All assets of the proprietary business were transferred to the partnership. Shares in assets: assessee 7/8, each daughter 1/16 (proportion to capital). Profits and losses divided equally among three partners.
The assessee was the managing partner with sole powers to sign cheques, borrow, execute documents, etc., retaining substantial control.
Partnership at will. Clause 2 allowed partners with major/minor capital share to continue business on notice, valuing shares including goodwill.
Deed recited assessee's desire to introduce major daughters and minor children upon majority. Provided for nomination by will/codicil.
No dissolution on death of partner; provisions for surviving partners and heirs.
Assessee filed return of gift tax for assessment year 1964-65 for gift of Rs. 50,000/- (Rs. 25,000/- to each daughter).

Gift Tax Officer (GTO) held additional gift of 2/3rd goodwill (valued at Rs. 1,07,910/- based on prior profits; total goodwill Rs. 1,61,865/-), added to Rs. 50,000/-, assessed tax. Invoked s.17(1)(c) for non-disclosure.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner (AAC) dismissed.
Appellate Tribunal held: (i) goodwill existing immovable property; (ii) gift exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv) for business expediency/continuity; (iii) only 1/8 share in goodwill gifted.
Tribunal referred three questions at instance of Commissioner: (1) goodwill existing property u/s 2(xii)? (2) gifted 1/8th or 2/3rd? (3) exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv)?
Kerala High Court answered all in favor of assessee against Revenue (judgment dated October 9, 1967).
Assessee aged below 50, no evidence of weak health or daughters' specialized knowledge/experience.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the goodwill of the assessee's business is an existing property within the meaning of s. 2(xii) of the Gift Tax Act?
Whether on the facts and circumstances, the assessee gifted only a 1/8th share in the goodwill or a 2/3rd share?
Whether on the facts and circumstances, the gift was exempt from assessment under s. 5(1)(xiv) of the Gift Tax Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Goodwill constituted a separate gift of 2/3rd share apart from Rs. 50,000/-, valued at Rs. 1,07,910/-, taxable.
Gift not exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv) as not made in the course of and bona fide for the purpose of business.

respondent_arguments.text: No separate gift of goodwill; entire assets valued at Rs. 4,00,000/- transferred proportionately to capital contributions; only admitted gift Rs. 50,000/-.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 14 Indian Partnership Act; partnership deed clauses

respondent_arguments.text: Gift exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv) for business continuity/expediency.

court_reasoning.text: Approach of authorities in isolating goodwill as separate gift incomprehensible; entire proprietary assets (including goodwill) transferred to partnership valued at Rs. 4,00,000/- proportionately; no gift tax on assets/goodwill.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No suggestion that entire Rs. 4,00,000/- assets were gift; picking only goodwill invalid.

court_reasoning.text: Reframed Q2: No gift tax payable on goodwill at all; Q1 does not arise.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Goodwill part of transferred assets per partnership deed and s.14 Partnership Act.

court_reasoning.text: Gift not in 'course of' business (requires connected relation) nor 'for the purpose' (object/design related to business); assessee retained control, no need for daughters' help, intent to benefit daughters/family succession, not business expediency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee admitted return for Rs.50,000/- gift; partnership at will, no evidence of business purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished from lower views; followed CGT v. Dr. George Kuruvilla (reversal of Kerala HC).

holdings.text: No gift tax payable on goodwill of assessee's business.
Assessee did not gift any share in goodwill subject to tax.
Gift of Rs. 50,000/- not exempt u/s 5(1)(xiv); taxable.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpretation of 'in the course of' requiring connected relation.
Preservation of business status within purpose of trade.
No dogmatic test for 'for the purpose of' business; fact-specific.

precedents_cited.case_name: CIT, West Bengal v. Birla Cotton Spinning & Weaving Mill Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: 'For purpose of business' wider than earning profits; includes preservation, commercial expediency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Gift Tax v. Dr. George Kuruvilla
precedents_cited.relevance: s.5(1)(xiv) requires proof of gift in course of and for purpose of business; reversed Kerala HC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Gift Tax, Kerala v. Dr. George Kuruvilla
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court view on exemption reversed by SC.

statutes_cited.name: Gift Tax Act, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of property; exemption for gifts in course of business; initiation of proceedings; reference to HC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Firm property includes goodwill brought into stock.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous to expenditure 'for purpose of business'.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court discharged High Court answers: No need to answer Q1; Q2 (reframed) no gift tax on goodwill (favor assessee); Q3 not exempt for Rs.50,000/- gift (favor Revenue). Appeal disposed accordingly.
outcome.relief_granted: No gift tax on goodwill; gift tax payable on Rs.50,000/-

key_quotes.text: 'This approach is wholly incomprehensible and no attempt has been made before us to justify it.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects isolating goodwill as separate taxable gift.

key_quotes.text: The expression 'in the course of carrying on of business etc. means that the gift should have some relationship with the carrying on of the business.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets 'in the course of' under s.5(1)(xiv).

key_quotes.text: 'the real intention of the assessee apparently was to take his daughters into the firm with the object of conferring benefit on them for the natural reason that the father wanted to look to the advancement of his daughters.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects business purpose; attributes to family benefit.
